children.subject: Will EE 120 be offered in Fall 2020? The website doesn't have it listed on the tentative schedule for fall right now: https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Scheduling/EE/schedule-draft.html.
I'd be surprised if it's not offered, but keep an eye on the draft schedule. If it is, I strongly +1 the recommendation to take 120! One of my absolute favorite classes.
Could you elaborate as to how 120 would be useful from a SWE perspective?
I really really advise 120 even if you're cs focused it's super helpful and if you're lucky enough to have Babak as professor, even better!
Does it require you know some control stuffs (like 16B level) before taking it?

It's not necessary, but having 16B level lin alg, diff eq, state modeling, and general mathematical maturity will make your life easier. The only "strict" (although nothing is enforced) pre-reqs were freshman linear algebra and 61A/61B level programming (although I would say having a high-school physics background is pretty helpful). Of course, if you're shaky in some topic office hours are always a resources to help with understanding concepts. The background of you and your teammates will also steer you towards the final project you choose.

I recommend EECS 106A! You don't need EE 120 (unless you want your final project to be related to controls research lol), the prereq list is outdated. The content is stuff you may not have touched on before, as the class covers a lot of ground with regard to mathematical modeling of rigid motion and in general how to represent things moving relative to other things in 3D space, along with other robotics related subdomains like vision, control, planning, etc. The homework and labs duo well to reinforce both theory and applications of material, before stopping altogether by midterm 2 by which you will start work on your final project, which is very open ended. Choose a project you're passionate about and you may get a nice capstone experience for your last semester :)

+1, even though it can get really tough at points, CS162 was my favorite class and definitely most impactful in terms of sheer learning. If you're interested in systems (OS, distributed systems, databases, etc) at all, please take this class!
CS 162 was a really cool class! Very useful class and a lot of fun too.

I'd say either 162 or 164:  Both are BIG systems-building classes.  I'd actually personally vote for 164 with Hilfinger:  The workload for Hilfinger 164 is really no different than others and you have the advantage of writing a lot of your code in Java rather than C which is a bit more failure tolerant.

I really enjoyed the algo courses in the 170 series. If 176 (Computational Biology) is offered next semester, I'd highly suggest taking it. That's my all-time favorite class. If it isn't offered, I vote for 164 which also satisfied my itch for algorithms.

You can look into Cryptography, a new class, if it is going to be offered next semester. Its basically 170 and 161 combined. You seemed to like 161 a lot, so if you liked diffie helman and want to put proofs and a tiny bit of math into it this would be very cool for you I think. No projects or coding though, its really more 170 than 161 tbh.

EDIT: I checked the draft schedule, and unfortunately Cryptography will only be offered after you graduate. :C

Plenty of special topics and grad courses you can take or audit as well. There's a grad security course offered sometimes, so you can look into that as well.

history.content:
I am graduating in December !! and with all the non-EECS courses I want to take and the fact that I've finished the major, I'll probably take at most 1 more EECS class. Was wondering what classes people have really enjoyed and if someone could offer some insight into what they've liked / haven't liked. 

Courses I've taken so far:

  • (taken all the lower divs; currently taking 16B. I liked all of them except maybe 16A. I do like building circuits and think labs are fun, I just don't like circuits very much)
  • CS 170 -- I thought this class was interesting, although I got too lazy for the homework assignments by the end. I thought the tests were really fun though! Algorithms are interesting.
  • CS 188 -- One of my favorite upper divs ever, I thought the material was super super interesting and the projects were very fun.
  • EECS 127 -- I thought the material was interesting, but it was a bit too much math for me. I also didn't do very well in this class because I gave up on the homework (there's !! a pattern here !!). Don't think I'd be able to take another class that's just (non-discrete) math again.
  • Data 100 -- Thought the material was a little too easy and kind of all over the place, but it was a very useful class in the end! Wasn't my favorite class, wasn't my least favorite class.
  • CS 194 (Computational + Social Networks) -- Class was a little easy, but interesting!
  • CS 189 (current) -- I like this class so far, although I must profess I'm not very caught up on material so I won't be able to offer the best opinion on it until after the midterm.
  • CS 161 (current) -- Probably on par with 188 as my two favorite EECS upper divs; I really love everything about this class! Material is interesting and projects are super fun.

Classes I'm considering taking (but am unsure about):

  • CS 182 (seems natural for post-189, but I'm not sure)
  • CS 164 (I think programming languages are interesting!)
  • EECS 106A (but would it be problematic that I haven't taken EE120?)

that being said, if you have a course that you would Die For please let me know!! I'm open to any course since I'm trying to have a ~ fun ~ last semester with courses I really enjoy / am interested in. any insight would be appreciated ^-^ for reference, I'm going to work in industry for a while before going back to grad school in not-EECS, but I've had several internships and don't particularly care about taking the "you should take this if you're going to work in software" classes. more than anything, I want things that are fun and interesting and let me solve puzzles, since that's why I'm an EECS major!

(also open to grad classes but some seem a lil ~ scary ~)
history.subject: What should be my last EECS class!
